content:
AgNCs were synthesized by using a previously reported polyol reaction. The AgNO3 precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 0.2 g of AgNO3 and 44 μL of 0.043 M CuCl2 (1,5-pentanediol solution) in 5 mL of 1,5-pentanediol. The other precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 0.1 g of PVP in 5 mL of 1,5-pentanediol. 1,5-Pentanediol was heated to 193 °C with continuous stirring in an oil bath. The AgNO3 and PVP precursor solutions were alternately injected into the hot 1,5-pentanediol with an injection rate of 500 μL/min (quick injection) and 320 μL/30 s (dropwise), respectively. The size of AgNCs can be controlled by the amount of precursor injection into the reaction batch. Postsynthetic purification was required to achieve the high quality (shape and size) of AgNCs. The as-made AgNC colloidal solution possessed ∼20% other shape impurities, such as triangular, spherical, and wirelike nanocrystals reduced to <5%, after postsynthetic filtration with a 450 nm filter paper twice and then filtration with a 220 nm filter paper several times.

Fabrication of the Core–Shell MOF-AgNC Nanocomposite

MOF-801-on-AgNC templates were synthesized by using a previously reported procedure. Acetic acid (AA) (2 mL) was well-dispersed in 8 mL of DI water in a 20 mL glass vial, and then, MPA-coated AgNC–PS–glass and MPA-coated AgNC–PS–silicon substrates were mounted and hung on AA aqueous solution with magnetic stirring (set up as shown in the schematic in Supporting Information Figure S25). Moreover, 6 μL of 30 mM Zr­(acac)4 solution (146 mg of Zr­(acac)4 was dissolved in 4 and 6 mL of DI water) and 9 μL of 20 mM fumaric acid solution (23.4 mg of fumaric acid in 10 mL of DI water) were injected every 60 min. The time-dependent optical properties can be characterized by the measurement of the extinction spectrum of the MOF-AgNC–PS–glass substrate. The reaction ended with the wavelength change in the HQ plasmon mode of AgNCs (ΔλHQ) of ∼54 nm. Moreover, the morphology of the MOF-AgNC nanocomposite can be observed by SEM and HRTEM.

Fabrication of the Corner MOF-AgNC Nanocomposite

MOF-801-on-AgNC templates were synthesized by using a previously reported procedure. Acetic acid (AA) (1 mL) was well-dispersed in 9 mL of DI water in a 20 mL glass vial, and then, MPA-coated AgNC–PS–glass and MPA-coated AgNC–PS–silicon substrates were mounted and hung on AA aqueous solution with magnetic stirring (set up as shown in the schematic in Supporting Information Figure S25). Moreover, 6 μL of 30 mM Zr­(acac)4 solution (146 mg of Zr­(acac)4 was dissolved in 4 and 6 mL of DI water) and 9 μL of 20 mM fumaric acid solution (23.4 mg of fumaric acid in 10 mL of DI water) were injected every 60 min. The time-dependent optical properties can be characterized by the measurement of the extinction spectrum of the MOF-AgNC–PS–glass substrate. The reaction ended with the wavelength change in the HQ plasmon mode of AgNCs (ΔλHQ) of ∼42 nm. Moreover, the morphology of the MOF-AgNC nanocomposite can be observed by SEM and HRTEM.

Synthesis of Silver Nanocubes (AgNCs)

AgNCs were synthesized by using a previously reported polyol reaction. The AgNO3 precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 0.2 g of AgNO3 and 44 μL of 0.043 M CuCl2 (1,5-pentanediol solution) in 5 mL of 1,5-pentanediol. The other precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 0.1 g of PVP in 5 mL of 1,5-pentanediol. 1,5-Pentanediol was heated to 193 °C with continuous stirring in an oil bath. The AgNO3 and PVP precursor solutions were alternately injected into the hot 1,5-pentanediol with an injection rate of 500 μL/min (quick injection) and 320 μL/30 s (dropwise), respectively. The size of AgNCs can be controlled by the amount of precursor injection into the reaction batch. Postsynthetic purification was required to achieve the high quality (shape and size) of AgNCs. The as-made AgNC colloidal solution possessed ~20% other shape impurities, such as triangular, spherical, and wirelike nanocrystals reduced to <5%, after postsynthetic filtration with a 450 nm filter paper twice and then filtration with a 220 nm filter paper several times.

Fabrication of the Core-Shell MOF-AgNC Nanocomposite

MOF-801-on-AgNC templates were synthesized by using a previously reported procedure. Acetic acid (AA) (2 mL) was well-dispersed in 8 mL of DI water in a 20 mL glass vial, and then, MPA-coated AgNC-PS-glass and MPA-coated AgNC-PS-silicon substrates were mounted and hung on AA aqueous solution with magnetic stirring (set up as shown in the schematic in Supporting Information Figure S25). Moreover, 6 μL of 30 mM Zr(acac)4 solution (146 mg of Zr(acac)4 was dissolved in 4 and 6 mL of DI water) and 9 μL of 20 mM fumaric acid solution (23.4 mg of fumaric acid in 10 mL of DI water) were injected every 60 min. The time-dependent optical properties can be characterized by the measurement of the extinction spectrum of the MOF-AgNC-PS-glass substrate. The reaction ended with the wavelength change in the HQ plasmon mode of AgNCs (ΔλHQ) of ~54 nm. Moreover, the morphology of the MOF-AgNC nanocomposite can be observed by SEM and HRTEM.

Fabrication of the Corner MOF-AgNC Nanocomposite

MOF-801-on-AgNC templates were synthesized by using a previously reported procedure. Acetic acid (AA) (1 mL) was well-dispersed in 9 mL of DI water in a 20 mL glass vial, and then, MPA-coated AgNC-PS-glass and MPA-coated AgNC-PS-silicon substrates were mounted and hung on AA aqueous solution with magnetic stirring (set up as shown in the schematic in Supporting Information Figure S25). Moreover, 6 μL of 30 mM Zr(acac)4 solution (146 mg of Zr(acac)4 was dissolved in 4 and 6 mL of DI water) and 9 μL of 20 mM fumaric acid solution (23.4 mg of fumaric acid in 10 mL of DI water) were injected every 60 min. The time-dependent optical properties can be characterized by the measurement of the extinction spectrum of the MOF-AgNC-PS-glass substrate. The reaction ended with the wavelength change in the HQ plasmon mode of AgNCs (ΔλHQ) of ~42 nm. Moreover, the morphology of the MOF-AgNC nanocomposite can be observed by SEM and HRTEM.
